pros: Close Knit, Good Management, Great Location
cons: The consistent travel gets tiresome if you do not like to travel.

pros: There is no one who ever reviews your work, gives any feedback, or checks on what you are doing ever...at all..so you can literally do whatever you want! Also, you can work without seeing a single colleague and you don't ever have to do any collaboration unless you go looking for it.
cons: The make decisions to offer certificate programs without any research and add to the administrative bloat, but they leave no money to invest in existing programs or professional development for faculty. There is no opportunity to develop any leadership and when those opportunities do arise, Regis prefers that you take on these things unpaid--you know be a good Christian! Also, the DEI is merely performative and lip service.

job_title: Student Support Coach in Weston, MA
pros: Hybrid schedule Summer fridays Education opportunities
cons: Below market salaries with little room to grow

pros: Flexible and great students. People seem to care.
cons: Top heavy so workload can be a lot. Shifting priorities.

pros:
Caring staff members
Mission focused 
work/life balance
cons:
hard to receive promotion
pay could be improved

pros: Regis is truly a mission-driven, student-focused college with an extremely supportive and affable staff and faculty. You hear the word "community" often but that is truly an apt description for this institution.
cons: Their endowment is not as robust as others in higher ed and their resources are fairly lean, but I think the people more than make up for it.

pros: Lots of freedom and not much supervison
cons: No metorship and no money for additional scholarship

job_title: Director of Corporate and Foundation Relations in Weston, MA
pros: Top mission, mission-driven, great people
cons: Understaffed, hard to make forward progress

review_title: Great community, opportunities for growth and promotion
job_title: Assistant Dean of Student Affairs in Weston, MA
pros: I have loved working at Regis! There is a great, small, tight-knit community. Suprisingly, it affords you tons of opportunity for growth and promotion - something virtually impossible in Higher Education. Since it's small you get opportunities to work in other areas and new projects beyond your job description.
cons:
It is not very diverse, but it is making progress
Some areas of the college have a very different culture and its not as supportive as Student Affairs

pros: Some colleagues and students are good to work with.
cons: Administrative bloat and mismanagement, extremely political environment.

pros: Friendly Atmosphere, Flexible Schedule, can make extra money above base pay by teaching extra classes
cons: A great place to work, no cons

job_title: Assistant Professor, Nursing in Weston, MA
pros: Mission, opportunity for growth, free education for employee and family members
cons: Salary is lowest in the area, administration does not always back faculty- go behind your back to change grades for fear of losing out on future tuition. Heavy workload. Lots of administrative "drama"

pros: Nice people, tuition remission for FT staff
cons: Not enough parking on campus

pros: Business Department well organized. Very friendly colleagues. Nice campus.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: Was a great place to work at one time....
pros:
- A few really good, decent people
- pretty campus
cons:
- too many “upper management” types and not enough staff to actually do the work
- implement MAJOR projects (such as the online programs) without much planning or consideration of infrastructure
- certain departments seemed to think they knew how to better run other departments
- the student services center seemed to be imploding
- was a very toxic environment. It’s obvious the academic council doesn’t get along so everything is a battle and nothing ever gets accomplished because no one is willing to compromise
- outdated labs classrooms and facilities
- complete lack of standards, integrity and transparency
- most staff are really good at what they do and willing to go the extra mile, but why should they when it’s not appreciated or recognized?

pros:
A pretty campus
Friendly people
Some really interesting things going on on campus
Free classes for employees
No many micromanagers at least in my experience
cons:
Horrible parking situation
Institutionally disorganized
A lot of programs pursued haphazardly
They knee-jerk react too often rather than strategically implement
Poor onboarding process for employees
Poor benefits when it comes to health insurance, time off, sick days

review_title: This was a good place to work. There were a lot of great people and good job opportunities in a number of different are
pros: Kind people, diversity, personal growth, flexibility, training was good.  The College has a lot of great values and beliefs that they bring to the table.  They have a lot of smart, kind people working there.
cons: It was hard to move up the corporate ladder per sue.  Although, the supervisors were supportive and understanding.  It is also a small work environment which can be both good and bad.

review_title: Need to stand by the mission...
pros: The mission of the school is everything. Dunks on campus. Beautiful campus. The school has great academic opportunities, again, by their mission.
cons: Not all agree or adhere to the mission of the school- some of which are in leadership positions. It is awful to feel like you are going to school who accepts all without distinction to only feel like an outsider. Tuition remission, but not for all.

pros: A friendly place to work. People are nice and professional. Positive learning environment. Always something new on the horizon. Students are interested and engaging.
cons: Parking situation is ridiculous. Administration is reluctant to enforce parking rules and rectify the situation. It is unlikely to change any time soon.

pros: The IT, library and other administrative personnel are very helpful and responsive, as are the faculty and leadership. There is a Dunkin Donuts on campus.
cons: On the whole, the students are woefully unprepared to participate in college-level learning. They do not accept responsibility for their own learning, and they are 100% extrinsically motivated. The concept that the reward is in the learning is foreign, even objectionable, to them. They chit chat in class ceaselessly and rarely do their homework. They wear pajamas to class, openly shop online during lectures, only do in-class work if it will be collected and graded, and giggle uproariously when their friends hoot at them from the hallway. The buildings are in terrible shape, the heating system is erratic, and there is almost never parking for faculty due to the frequency with which the institution hosts events. The learning management systems are cumbersome and department-driven curricula and assessment tools are ineffective. Prescribed rubrics barely scratch the surface of what a good assessment tool can do.

pros: Head swim coach was great to work for. Very helpful and professional
cons: Athletic Administration was an absolute mess. There was no transparency in their words or actions. So much gossip felt like I was back in high school. Did not feel supported as a female in the Athletics Department.

review_title: Don't even think about working at Regis...
pros: The friends I made who felt the same.
cons: Where do I begin? A president who has no fund-raising skills whatsoever and absolutely no idea how to run a college. Way too many VPs who are in positions of power with no previous experience. A demand for loyalty to the "powers that be" with little to no regard for students. I'm embarrassed to admit I ever worked at this joke of a school.

pros:
Great spirit of collaboration and support for new initiatives.
Friendly environment.
cons:
Salaries are kept below average unless you are a star.
Disconnection between some key units.

pros: Lived mission. Engaging colleagues. Impassioned students.
cons: Like many places, some long time employees are resistant to growth/change.

pros: Dedicated colleagues who really care about education and social justice.  Inclusive, diverse community.  Non-hierarchical, cooperative.  Plenty of opportunity for innovation and advancement.  Excellent work-life balance.
cons: Salaries are not high.  Limited office space.

job_title: Admission Systems Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great environment, people are supportive and opportunity for growth.
cons: Develop upper management with stronger managerial skills. Offer managerial professional development.

pros: Great pay, time off when needed
cons: Staff are clique-y and don't want to be on the bad side of Admin staff

review_title: Great place to work during college
pros: Friendly environment, is sympathetic to students needs.
cons: no cons are available at this moment

pros: Small Campus Weston PD have it together,
cons: Lack of Training & Professional Leadership total legal mess with some very unstable dept. members. No departmental leadership
